bill, im stuck in the same rut that you were once stuck in. I feel like I can't write songs. part of it comes from this feeling inside when I try to write that is something along the lines of "who do you think you are to be trying to write songs". I don't even know what to write about but I love music so much that I just have to make songs. what should I do?

a good method people sometimes use for tuning a guitar string, is to bend it far out of tune, and then bend it gradually back up into tune. well, i think this might be a good strategy for songwriting, if you are feeling lost. Shoot way outside the boundaries of what anyone may think a 'song' is supposed to be..... and then gradually dial it back into more reasonable territory. i guarantee there will be some wild discoveries along the way
With your music videos, do you ever change the song to match a new visual idea or are the songs (pretty much) set in stone beforehand?

do you think those 3-D glasses are cool?

the coolest ones are the RealD ones, but those unfortunately rely on having a special movie theater screen. For a regular screen, the only options i know of are red/blue, and mirror offset. red/blue makes your head wanna explode and it ruins the colors in the video. And with mirror offset, you're gonna see extra copies of the entire screen on either side. It seems like the only real viable option for 3D viewing is something that actually displays the video in front of each eye, like an AR or VR device

So if I were to theoretically say that I had a CSV filled with hundreds of hours of flight data and I used that, google flights and some other sources to make a detailed itinerary on how to visit every country with an airport exclusively by airplane, how would I best turn that into a video that wasn't just an elongated boring list?

don't elongate the list. just show the travel path geographically. if there are any moves that seem interesting to you, focus on those, and then speed up again through the 'boring' ones. which probably aren't boring if they are put all together. for example, if 12 moves go in an S pattern, don't focus on every indivisual move. focus on the S pattern. if 1 move takes 16 hours, focus on that one. etc. First thing to do is take a look at the itinerary and see what your thoughts are. the most important things to talk about, will probably be noticeable right away.

How come sometimes the enter button submits the question but sometimes it just adds a new line

(ref: q.php?date=202004201654)4.20.204:54 pm  I am curious about ideas generation process. When you have one idea on the piano, how long do you usually run with that? I've been getting back into creating music recently after a several years hiatus and I'm finding I am running with an idea for between 10 and 30 minutes or so before I can really move on to another totally different one. If i try earlier than that it is too similar. This is just idea Gen stage not songwriting so it feels way too slow. Any advice?

if you are looking for ways to come up with more different ideas quicker, you could try using various random prompts. a random image. a random word. maybe even a random song, and make it a goal that you are going to write a song in some way related to that song but definitely not that song. or you could use a movie as a starting point. you could even have a totally different type of session where you just come up with different types of starting points. then another type of session where you go through each of the starting points you came up with, and use them. you can use anything as a starting point, but ironically what often happens is if you generate ideas for a while, even if you seem like you're not getting enough, often as soon as you stop and do something else the ideas will fall on you. the truth is that ideas are everywhere, in every molecule. at the rate of about a kajillion ideas per molecule. so if you ever think there are not enough, the ideas will wait for you to stop paying attention and then laugh in your face, flaunting their abundance at you. the question is will you be quick enough on the button, to catch them, regardless of whether you are in the shower, a business meeting, in court, ........ and if the answer is yes then you know you're really in the game

okay big question. say i have a DAW that records me playing the keyboard, but i want the final sound of the recorded track to not be that of the keyboard preset i played live, but that of a plugin/one of those DAW instrument presets. basically, i don't want to use my keyboard to type all the notes if i don't need to. h o w in the world is this achieved? does the ability to record your physical playing of keyboard AS a plugin depend on the make of the keyboard? ps sorry this is long-winded, i'm a complete amateur and my music terminology is limited atm

i'm not entirely sure what you mean because it seems like some of the things you said go against other things you said ..... but if you are wondering how to record midi with a keyboard.... your keyboard needs to be a midi controller. and most of them are. in modern times that usually means you need to connect the keyboard with a USB cable, and then make sure you have the right MIDI driver installed on your computer (always available on the website for your keyboard.... so that would be the yamaha website, or korg website, roland, etc). and then you wanna tell your recording software that you are gonna record a MIDI track, not an audio track. then if you press record on a midi track, it will be listening for you to play your midi keyboard and it will record the midi data. and then you can use whatever sound you want, in the computer

How do I even begin to start learning how to make videos??? I tried just starting really simple using the programs built into my computer. And my goal was to make a video of just a black line moving horizontally across a white background. I used MS Paint, drew a line. Took a screen shot and saved it. Moved the line the tiniest smidge forward. Took another screen shot and saved it etc etc etc. Tried stringing all the screen shots together in MovieMaker for the final product. Well, it took me an ungodly amount of time to do this. I had to make and save approximately 1 zillion screen shots. And the final product was trash. It just looked like a choppy slideshow of a bunch of pictures of a line. No fluid motion (which was my goal). I don't know what to try now. I'm super frustrated and disheartened. My plan was to learn how to just make simple shapes moving across across a blank background and then gradually move forward towards more complex motion and m ore deta iled characters/backgrounds... But I can't even get a damn line to move across the screen with fluid motion. I know I'm not exactly using state of the art technology here but if I can't figure out how to do something extremely simple on an extremely simple program, investing in some fancy animation software probably isn't the smartest move... sorry for ranting at you, bill. I'm just upset.

ah yes, this is the typical overwhelm that occurs in animated visual media. there is much much more overwhelm where that came from, but, there are also solutions. For this particular situation, you'll want to look for something called "keyframes." Most video software has it. it will allow you to pick a point in time and space for the image to be, and then pick another point in time and space, and it connects them linearly (or, for your convenience and pleasure, sometimes it will do use a cringey curve algorhythm). If your software actually cannot do keyframes (which i think it can), i'm sure there is some other very basic and simple software that is within your budget that can

I am not literate in music theory, so I am interested if you can bring insight to this conundrum. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c0sCTj6hMsQ this is the soundtrack to the ending of a movie, where the protagonist kills herself. If you listen to the track, this may seem surprising;the music isn't what one might associate with such tragedy. People in the comment section are grappling as to whether or not this is 'sad' music, and trying to comprehend what a confusing feeling it is to listen. There is some consensus that this really just 'neutral' music, meant to convey the idea that death is neutral. This is how I myself understand it.
There is one individual however, who is dead insistent and a bit aggressive that this is JOYOUS music simply because music theory says so. Major key == happy. Case closed. The fact that one is reminded of something separate should not be considered...
This blunt use of music theory stresses me out a bit. Is that somewhat true? Or not?

'major key == happy' is not quite true. you can easily make a dreadfully sad song in a major key. also, my opinion from listening to the music you linked, is that it is extremely joyous. not 'because it's in a major key', but because it simply sounds extremely joyous. from listening to it

the way it sounds, and the feelings it evokes, from the sounds, when paired with whatever context it's in

Bill, I have an issue. I like to make projects, cool little events, sometimes a little funny video, perhaps a map to a video game and so on. But for years I've been struggling with three big problems.

First, when thinking about starting a project, I tend to struggle getting it started. In my mind I have this feeling that I know exactly what to do, but starting it just feels exhausting and I don't get things done. How do I kickstart myself to start those projects?

it sounds like you still don't know specifically enough, the first steps. what helps me is to put on my own tv show, even if it's not actually on tv. you are the host of the show, and on the show, you will discuss and figure out how the hell to do the thing you are trying to do. and it will be fun and exciting as the audience follows along with your quest

Second, when I get things started, I have this bad trait where I work on projects marathon style. For example, I do something for multiple days nonstop, but if I take even a smallest pause (like one day), the project just freezes instantly. How do I get rid of this marathon mentality?
very specific bookmarks will help. write down exactly where you left off. very very specifically exactly what the next exact thing is.

Third, even if things are rolling, sometimes I start to think elsewhere. "Damn, that's a great idea!" New projects that I should absolutely do! But there's this other project I' m alread y working on and that would just give me extra work. How does one simply focus on one project at a time while maintaining other amazing, potential ideas?
keep an idea bank. add ideas to it. watch the bank grow out of control

the default 'normal' sound, for time, tends to run in powers of 2. so lengths of 2, 4, 8, 16, are all normal sounding lengths. here's the thing: don't use it if you don't need it. but if you are curious about what it does, go ahead and turn all the low frequencies down, and leave the high ones up. then listen. then put it back, and then turn the high frequencies down, and keep the low ones up. now listen. i think you will now understand exactly what it does. (you may recall this from knobs on a music player for 'treble' and 'bass', but this is the more detailed version of that.) So now, if you listen to something, and you notice it has too much low, or too much high, or not enough low or not enough high, etc etc, now you might now what to do. but please don't use it if the sound already sounded fine. that's the golden rule

what is your musical writing process?

the first step is to learn how to catch the ideas as they fall out of the sky at unexpected times, and put them all in the same place. the next thing is to learn how to figure out which one to choose, when it's time to do one. i have zeroed in on a hybrid random-nonrandom selection scheme which works very reliably for me. then i just have to recover all documentation on that item and figure out how the rest of it's supposed to go. always go from beginning to end, unless the piece you already have is not the beginning ..... in which case you will have to work backwards, which is extremely impossible, but i am proud to say i have learned how to do it (long journey, outside, got to know,) and then to figure out what comes next, must do timed run throughs after a door touch refresh, and pay very keen attention when approaching the cliff. catch whatever you catch, and then discuss briefly in yes or no questions, then when you've exhausted all lines of reasoning, go back to the door and run it again

Okay, so, the answer about the stacked same exact voicings per octave got me thinking: I can see how this technique could be useless in the context of a chord voicing spread throughout more than the space of an octave (at least), but what if I want to achieve some reinforcement over a certain voicing much like when some harmonic distortion is added to enrich or fatten a sound? Some mud may be necessary to be cut via EQing (if used in the wrong areas), but it seems like a valid production technique when trying to add some density while maintaining the harmonic colour, if you will.

absolutely, but it will NOT work if you use the exact same notes in a different octave. what you are trying to achieve will be achieved by using different notes, and i would be delighted to tell you which
Also, may add some stereo dimension when taking panning into account. What do you say?

as octaves go up and down, you need different amounts of notes to re enforce the same exact sound you had. using the same exact 'notes' in different octaves will make the sound different, in fact dare i say will weaken it and add an 'ick' factor. if you tell me any notes and exactly what octave they are in, i will give you my best suggestion(s) of how to re enforce it while keeping the exact same flavor. you can even tell me how much distortion you happen to have on it. i promise you the answer will never be the exact same notes in a different octave..... that's just not what's gonna re enforce the original sound.  the exception to this is if you started with only 1 note

I can't get in the studio with my band, so I'm sending them the individual instrument parts to record themselves, in their homes. Guitar and bass and keys can record through an interface, but I don't know how to get quality audio from the acoustic instruments. (For most of them, the only mic around is in their phone) How can we get clean takes from that kind of limited setup?

what stands out more to me in this situation are not concerns of acoustics, but concerns of how the band plays together (or, how to effectively simulate the phenomenon of the band actually playing together). one thing i will suggest is to do the drums first, so everyone else can hear the drums. that's just for the sake of the chemistry and the quality of everyone playing together. Actually, what i would really recommend is, after doing the drums first, send it to the chordal instruments, then send it to vocals, then send it to bass, then send it back to the drummer with drums muted and a very strong click (oh i forgot to mention you absolutely must have the click in there from the start), then send it back to the chordal instrument(s) and have them re-do that, with the new drums included, then maybe send it to bass to have that redone, then back to vocals, keep going around like this and have the people re-do their parts each time, because each time it gets closer and closer to creating the illusion of people actually playing together, because now they are hearing each other... even better, they are hearing each other do what they did while hearing each other. but i just realized you probably already knew all this. but as far as acoustics, just remember that some people spend millions of dollars on ways to try to deliberately simulate bad acoustics. hope that helps

how did you make that color expanding across the land effect in HOJ and HOTEWIG?

the trick is to take the image of the full map, duplicate the file, then use the lasso selector to outline what you want, copy, select all, delete, paste, then open a blank black image, select all, copy that, go back to the isolated territory file, then paste, undo, select all, copy, redo, paste. now you have an outlined territory on black background, on an image file the same exact size as another image which includes the whole map. then import both those images into your video timeline, and perform the movements you need, get the movements copied to both images, put the partially black one on top, then key out the black, edge feather, then tint the color. can also double layer and composite  the cut-out one, as desired. to make it expand, you can use a simple crop line with edge feather, keyframed in before and after positions, or if you need it to go at an angle, you can use a rectangular mask shape at an angle. maybe even use a circular mask shape and have that expand. the key to the game is making sure your 2 images (one of the full map and one of just the territory on black background) are exactly the same dimensions, so that way you can easily apply the exact same movements to both of them. In a 3D environment such as history of the world, this is done with video files. render the globe moving as you want, with the full map on it, then replace the globe map with a same sized map with only the desired territory, and the rest black. re-render the exact same sequence, with exactly the same start and end time. then import both videos into your 2D timeline, and stack them, and key out the black, as before

Are you trying to change your style?

there are some basic advancements that seem to be inevitable, and it was actually a peculiar case of software obscelecense which triggered the transition, which was due to happen sometime anyway but i just wasn't sure when
Please elaborate. What do you have to learn?

the core software that i was using for video production was discontinued, actually around 2012 (before i even started using it). but by the time i found out, i was already 2 or 3 years down the road of experience with it. so i was clinging to an old computer system, year after year, and couldn't update or i would have to relearn all the tricks and techniques i had accumulated. But, there's also a secondary piece of software that i've been using in addition, ever since about 2016, to do some of the 3D elements, and sometime last year when starting on a music video i just felt deep inside that i wanted to try starting off the entire video from the 3D program, just to see what happens. i've always known 3D is a nightmare mindfuck timesink, but something must have clicked in my biological timeclock or something, and i realized it was my destiny to just jump into it, and apply all the same principles of brutal simplicity that had allowed me first enter the video making realm (an equally impossible mindfuck, back then, having had no experience). So i fell hopelessly in love with this new realm, despite some of the unthinkable challenges, and then it occured to me that this is obviously the time when i am supposed to make the jump to a new system. there is literally every reason to do it, and equally many reasons 'not' to 'not' do it. it's kind of like going through puberty. your body says it's time to change and the change happens. and let's just say that the transition has set into motion so many more ridiculous and exciting developments than i had ever could have expected, and yet needed so desperetly all along. it's like when a tree grows for 10 years under a small shelf and then the shelf breaks and the tree suddenly explodes in an upward direction. could be awkward at first but you know it's gotta happen. if you've known me, you'll know i've been through this many times before
